hints_html: Try evaluating the limit directly. Pay attention to the directional limit - the fact that this is a right hand limit will impact the sign of your answer.
hints_latex:
Try evaluating the limit directly. Pay attention to the directional
limit - the fact that this is a right hand limit will impact the sign of
your answer.
hints_raw: Try evaluating the limit directly.  Pay attention to the directional limit - the fact that this is a right hand limit will impact the sign of your answer.
question: 2 (b)
sols_html:
We can evaluate this limit directly. We start by evaluating what happens to \(\sin x\) and \(\cos x\) as \(x \to 0^+\). Because this is a directional limit from the right, we will have \(\sin x \to 0^+\) (on a sine graph, as you approach x = 0 from the right, the y value is approaching zero from above, hence approaching \(0^+\)) and \(\cos x \to 1^-\) (similarly, approaching x = 0 from the right on a cosine graph means approaching y = 1 from below, hence \(1^-\)). Replacing \(\sin x\) with y and \(\cos x\) with z, we can thus rewrite the limit as a fraction of the limits:

\[\begin{aligned} \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = \frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)}\end{aligned}\]

Again, the fact that this is a directional limit means that for the first limit, as \(y \to 0^+\), \(\ln(y) \to -\infty\) and for the second limit, as \(z \to 1^-\), \(\ln(z) \to 0^-\). So we have:

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)} = \frac{-\infty}{0^-}\end{aligned}\]

Recall that when a function goes to zero from the left in the denominator, this means that we eventually divide by a very small negative value (for example, -1/100000). Using fraction rules, this very small value in the denominator is the same as multiplying by a very large negative value (in my example, -100000) in the numerator. Thus going to zero in the denominator corresponds to multiplying the numerator by a very large number. Since our numerator is already going to negative infinity, the fact that we have \(0^-\) in the denominator will make the value of the limit greater, and turn it back from negative to positive. Thus the value of this limit is \(+\infty\),

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = +\infty\end{aligned}\]
sols_latex:
We can evaluate this limit directly. We start by evaluating what happens
to $\sin x$ and $\cos x$ as $x \to 0^+$. Because this is a directional
limit from the right, we will have $\sin x \to 0^+$ (on a sine graph, as
you approach \emph{x = 0} from the right, the \emph{y} value is
approaching zero \emph{from above}, hence approaching $0^+$) and
$\cos x \to 1^-$ (similarly, approaching \emph{x = 0} from the right on
a cosine graph means approaching \emph{y = 1} from below, hence $1^-$).
Replacing $\sin x$ with \emph{y} and $\cos x$ with \emph{z}, we can thus
rewrite the limit as a fraction of the limits:

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = \frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)}
\end{align*}

Again, the fact that this is a directional limit means that for the
first limit, as $y \to 0^+$, $\ln(y) \to -\infty$ and for the second
limit, as $z \to 1^-$, $\ln(z) \to 0^-$. So we have:

\begin{align*}
\frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)} = \frac{-\infty}{0^-}
\end{align*}

Recall that when a function goes to zero from the left in the
denominator, this means that we eventually divide by a very small
negative value (for example, -1/100000). Using fraction rules, this very
small value in the denominator is the same as multiplying by a very
large negative value (in my example, -100000) in the numerator. Thus
going to zero in the denominator corresponds to multiplying the
numerator by a very large number. Since our numerator is already going
to negative infinity, the fact that we have $0^-$ in the denominator
will make the value of the limit greater, and turn it back from negative
to positive. Thus the value of this limit is $+\infty$,

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = +\infty
\end{align*}
sols_raw:
We can evaluate this limit directly.  We start by evaluating what happens to <math>\sin x</math> and <math>\cos x</math> as <math>x \to 0^+</math>.  Because this is a directional limit from the right, we will have <math>\sin x \to 0^+</math> (on a sine graph, as you approach ''x = 0'' from the right, the ''y'' value is approaching zero ''from above'', hence approaching <math>0^+</math>) and <math>\cos x \to 1^-</math> (similarly, approaching ''x = 0'' from the right on a cosine graph means approaching ''y = 1'' from below, hence <math>1^-</math>).  Replacing <math>\sin x</math> with ''y'' and <math>\cos x</math> with ''z'', we can thus rewrite the limit as a fraction of the limits: 

:<math>\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = \frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)}</math>

Again, the fact that this is a directional limit means that for the first limit, as <math>y \to 0^+</math>, <math>\ln(y) \to -\infty</math> and for the second limit, as <math>z \to 1^-</math>, <math>\ln(z) \to 0^-</math>.  So we have: 


:<math>\frac{\lim_{y \to 0^+} \ln(y)}{\lim_{z \to 1^-} \ln(z)} = \frac{-\infty}{0^-}</math>

Recall that when a function goes to zero from the left in the denominator, this means that we eventually divide by a very small negative value (for example, -1/100000).  Using fraction rules, this very small value in the denominator is the same as multiplying by a very large negative value (in my example, -100000) in the numerator.  Thus going to zero in the denominator corresponds to multiplying the numerator by a very large number.  Since our numerator is already going to negative infinity, the fact that we have <math>0^-</math> in the denominator will make the value of the limit greater, and turn it back from negative to positive.  Thus the value of this limit is <math>+\infty</math>,

:<math> \displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)} = +\infty
</math>
statement_html:
Evaluate the following limit, if it exists.

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)}\end{aligned}\]
statement_raw:
''Evaluate the following limit, if it exists.''

:<math> \displaystyle
\lim_{x \to 0^+} \frac{\ln(\sin x)}{\ln(\cos x)}
</math>
